, &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hyperventilation and\nabnormal electrical signals in the brain take place simultaneously.&nbsp; Chest breathing results in drastic reduction\nof blood oxygenation since lower parts of the lungs get more than 7&nbsp; times richer blood supply.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Adverse&nbsp; biochemical and immune effects of mouth/\nchest breathing are too numerous and too shocking to even expound . <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Our diaphragm flattens\nwhen we are stressed and we begin to breathe shallowly and faster , which\nraises our stress level even more. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Changing your breathing\npattern is an important step in reducing stress. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When we do deep\ndiaphragmatic breathing, our stress levels will decrease because it allows more\noxygen to flow through the body.&nbsp; Yogic\nbreathing puts us in a parasympathetic (calm and relaxed) from a sympathetic\n(fight or flight) nervous system.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It\noptimizes the carbon dioxide (CO2) and oxygen (O2) exchange in the lungs to\ngive greater space in the thoracic cavity during inhalation.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A better CO2/O2 exchange\nalso allows for higher oxygen saturation in our blood. Deep diaphragmatic\nbreathing stimulates the cleansing work of the lymph system by creating a\nnegative pressure pulling the lymph through the lymph system. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This increases the rate\nof elimination of toxins from visceral organs by more than 16 TIMES..&nbsp;&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Lymph nodes connected\nto the stomach, kidneys, liver, pancreas, spleen, large and small colons, and\nother vital organs are located just under the diaphragm - over 62% of all lymph\nnodes in total!<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; font-size: large;\"><b>When we breathe more\nair, by hyperventilation, we get less oxygen in body cells. </b></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In fact, the slower\nyour automatic breathing pattern at rest (down to only 3 breaths/min), the\nlarger the amount of oxygen delivered to cells. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hyperventilation occurs\nwhen the rate and quantity of alveolar ventilation of carbon dioxide exceeds\nthe body's production of carbon dioxide.&nbsp;\nHyperventilation can be voluntary or involuntary.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When alveolar\nventilation is excessive, more carbon dioxide will be removed from the blood\nstream than the body can produce.&nbsp; This\ncauses the concentration of carbon dioxide in the blood stream to fall and\nproduces a state known as hypocapnia.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If excess ventilation\ncannot be compensated metabolically, it will lead to a rise in blood pH. This\nrise in blood pH is known as respiratory alkalosis. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><b><span style=\"color: red; font-size: large;\">I AM REPEATING CERTAIN\nTHINGS AGAIN AND AGAIN\u2014SO THAT YOU DON\u2019T MISS IT OUT LIKE A GOLD NUGGET IN A HAYSTACK</span></b><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: magenta; font-size: large;\">When hyperventilation\nleads to respiratory alkalosis, it may cause a number of physical symptoms:\ndizziness, tingling in the lips, hands or feet, headache, weakness, fainting\nand seizures. <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: magenta; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: magenta; font-size: large;\">In extreme cases it can\ncause carpopedal spasms (flapping and contraction of the hands and feet\u2014like what\nhappened to my wife at AOLs Sudarshan Kriya camp ) . <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: magenta; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; color: magenta; font-size: large;\">Low carbon dioxide\nlevels cause the brain's blood vessels to constrict, resulting in reduced blood\nflow to the brain and lightheadedness---this is NO god\u2019s miracle \u2013rather it is\na conman\u2019s dirty trick.</span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple; font-size: large;\">Hyperventilation leads\nto an excessive elimination of carbon dioxide (CO2) whereas no significant\nadditional amounts of oxygen can be stocked in the body. <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; color: purple; font-size: large;\">As only carbon dioxide\nis responsible for the breathing stimulus, after hyperventilation, breath can\nbe held longer until cerebral hypoxia occurs. </span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The blood also becomes\nabnormally alkaline as a result of the excessive elimination of carbon dioxide;\nthis subsequent rise in blood pH is termed alkalosis. Alkalosis interferes with\nnormal oxygen utilization by the brain. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The symptoms of\nalkalosis are neuromuscular irritability, muscular spasms, tingling and\nnumbness of the extremities and around the mouth, and a dizziness, or\ngiddiness, often interpreted as a sense of euphoria.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Because the brain\ncannot store reserves of oxygen and, unlike other organs, has an exceedingly\nlow tolerance of oxygen deprivation, it is highly vulnerable if\nvasoconstriction is not reversed. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Normally, if the brain\nis hypoxic, autonomous systems in the body divert blood to the brain at the\nexpense of other organs; because the brain is vasoconstricted this mechanism is\nnot available. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vasoconstriction is\nonly reversed by the build-up of carbon dioxide in the blood through suspension\nof breathing.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hypocapnia causes\ncerebral vasoconstriction, leading to cerebral hypoxia and this can cause\ntransient dizziness, visual disturbances, and anxiety. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A low partial pressure\nof carbon dioxide in the blood also causes alkalosis (because CO2 is acidic in\nsolution), leading to lowered plasma calcium ions and increased nerve and\nmuscle excitability. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This explains the other\ncommon symptoms of hyperventilation \u2014pins and needles, muscle cramps and tetany\nin the extremities, especially hands and feet.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Because the brain stem\nregulates breathing by monitoring the level of blood CO2, hypocapnia can\nsuppress breathing to the point of blackout from cerebral hypoxia.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hypocapnia reduces the\noxygen levels available to the brain due to the elevated affinity of oxygen to\nhemoglobin (Bohr effect) hence highly increasing the chances of blackout.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hypocapnia is a state\nof reduced carbon dioxide in the blood. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hypocapnia usually\nresults from deep or rapid breathing, known as hyperventilation.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A low partial pressure\nof carbon dioxide in the blood also causes alkalosis (because CO2 is acidic in\nsolution), leading to lowered plasma calcium ions and increased nerve and\nmuscle excitability. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This explains the other\ncommon symptoms of hyperventilation \u2014pins and needles, muscle cramps and tetany\nin the extremities, especially hands and feet.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Because the brain stem\nregulates breathing by monitoring the level of blood CO2, hypocapnia can\nsuppress breathing to the point of blackout from cerebral hypoxia.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Note : Lung air\npressure is increased by holding the breath \"hard\" or \"bearing\ndown\" -tightening the diaphragm as in a forced exhalation while allowing\nno air to escape.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hyperventilation leads\nto an excessive elimination of carbon dioxide (CO2) with&nbsp; no significant additional amounts of oxygen\nstored in the body.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As only carbon dioxide\nis responsible for the breathing stimulus, after hyperventilation, breath can\nbe held longer until cerebral hypoxia occurs. The blood becomes&nbsp; abnormally alkaline as a result of the&nbsp; excessive elimination of carbon dioxide;\nthis&nbsp; subsequent rise in blood pH is\ntermed alkalosis.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; color: purple;\">Alkalosis interferes\nwith normal oxygen utilization by the brain.&nbsp;</span></span></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; color: purple;\"><br /></span></span></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; color: purple;\">The symptoms of&nbsp; alkalosis are neuromuscular irritability,\nmuscular spasms, tingling and numbness of the&nbsp;\nextremities and around the mouth, and a dizziness, or giddiness, often\ninterpreted as a sense of euphoria by </span><b style=\"background-color: white;\"><span style=\"color: red;\">CONMEN who are India's yoga gurus sponsored by PM Modi&nbsp;</span></b></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hyperventilation, or\nover-breathing, does not add oxygen to arterial blood. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This is because under\nnormal physiological states arterial blood is close to saturation with respect\nto oxygen and is simply not able to absorb more.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hyperventilation has\nlittle effect on arterial pO2 and almost no effect on oxygen saturation which\nis nearly 100% under normal circumstances.&nbsp;&nbsp;\nIts main effect is to lower pCO2 and produce a respiratory alkalosis.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If we breathe within\nnormal parameters this mechanism works very well to deliver oxygen to brain and\nbody tissues.&nbsp; By contrast,\nover-breathing (i.e breathing more than the physiological norm) can upset this\ndelicate balance thereby reducing oxygen delivery to cells.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hyperventilation does\nnot only reduce the total cerebral blood flow, but also changes the\ndistribution of blood flow within the brain.&nbsp;\n<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Blood flow to the\nfrontal, occipital, and parieto-occipital cortex, as well as the hippocampus is\nreduced relative to other areas of the brain within seconds to minutes of\ncommencing hyperventilation.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; font-size: large;\"><b>I WILL REPEAT CERTAIN VITAL THINGS AGAIN AND AGAIN AND AGAIN</b></span></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The high pH value\nresulting from hyperventilation also reduces the level of available calcium\n(hypocalcemia), which affects the nerves and muscles, causing constriction of\nblood vessels and tingling. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">People with\nhyperventilation commonly describe symptoms such as disturbed mentation,\nimpaired concentration, poor memory, and hallucinations. Feelings of\ndepersonalization are also common, where hyperventilating persons describe\nsensations of unreality, or feeling everything is confused and dream-like. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hallucinating effects\nhave been used by FAKE gurus to make an ass out of devotees.. These stupid\ndevotees think the FAKE guru is god in a mortal body<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Visual experiences such\nas blurred vision, tunnel vision, flashing lights, and seeing double also\noccur).&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hyperventilation can\ncause brain death.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hyperventilation\nreduces the cerebral blood flow by causing constriction of the arteries\nsupplying the brain with blood<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Cerebral blood flow is\ndirectly related to the carbon dioxide pressure in the blood, and inversely\nrelated to the pH of the blood flowing through the arteries going to the brain\n.&nbsp;&nbsp; In other words, the lower the carbon\ndioxide pressure in the blood, the lower the cerebral blood flow&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hyperventilation causes\nloss of carbon dioxide from the body, causing the pH of blood to increase and\nbecome more alkaline. When blood is more alkaline, hemoglobin binds more\ntightly with oxygen. The primary urge to breathe is triggered by rising carbon\ndioxide (CO2) levels in the bloodstream. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">CO2 builds up in the\nbloodstream when O2 is metabolized and it needs to be expelled as a waste\nproduct. The body detects CO2 levels very accurately and relies on this to\ncontrol breathing. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Art of Living run by\nSri Sri Ravishankar has made false claims that SO HUM SUDARSHAN KRIYA ,\nHYPERVENTILATION&nbsp; can cure cancer and\nAIDS, be used as a treatment for drug addiction, treat depression, improve\nsleep, improve focus and concentration, and that it is effective in reducing\nstress. Now they are busy deleting these false claims <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The problem with\nhyperventilation comes from blowing off too much carbon dioxide. We tend to see\nCO2 as a waste product, something to be disposed of. But in fact we need to\nkeep&nbsp; CO2 in the blood within a certain\nrange, because it plays an important role in maintaining blood pH. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As CO2 levels drop\nduring hyperventilation, the result is a higher, or more alkaline, pH. when\nblood becomes more alkaline, hemoglobin (the molecule that transports oxygen in\nthe red blood cells) tends to hold on more tightly to oxygen.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This makes sense\nin the context of allocating oxygen to the tissues that need it most:\nmetabolically active tissues that have consumed a lot of oxygen and need to\nreplenish it will have also produced a lot of CO2.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This creates a more acidic\nlocal environment, which in turn causes hemoglobin to release more oxygen. The\nreverse is true when conditions are more alkaline; tissues don\u2019t get as much\noxygen, because hemoglobin hangs on to it.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thus, the brain gets hit with a\ndouble whammy during hyperventilation\u2014less blood flow, plus less oxygen being\nreleased from the blood<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When CO2 levels in the\nblood drop, pH rises. This alkaline shift causes changes in a blood-borne\nprotein called albumin. Albumin then binds to calcium, reducing the amount of\nfree calcium in circulation. This in turn causes peripheral nerves to become\nmore excitable. These hair trigger nerves then fire repeatedly, sending signals\nto muscles that cause them to contract involuntarily. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The primary inputs that\nstimulate breathing come from sensors known as chemoreceptors, which\ncontinuously sample the chemical composition of body fluids. Some\nchemoreceptors are sensitive to oxygen; when arterial oxygen levels decline,\nthey trigger an inhale. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Under normal\ncircumstances, though, oxygen levels don\u2019t drop low enough to stimulate these\nreceptors. They are like a thermostat turned way down; they only click on when\noxygen levels are very low, and thus serve more as a last resort than a day in,\nday out regulator of breathing.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Other chemoreceptors\nare sensitive to car carbon dioxide levels. Those located in the brain stem are\nthe primary regulators of breathing rate. Technically, they don\u2019t sense carbon\ndioxide; rather they test the pH of the cerebrospinal fluid (the fluid bath the\nbrain and spinal cord float in). <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red; font-size: large;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">However, since the\nprime determinant of cerebrospinal pH is the carbon dioxide level in the blood,\nit amounts to the same thing. These sensors are far more sensitive than oxygen\nsensors; even a small RISE &nbsp;in CO2 levels\nwill cause them to fire, sending a signal to the respiratory center to trigger\nan inhale.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thus, we could say that, by and large, we don\u2019t breathe to take in\noxygen, but to get rid of CO2 at the proper amount .&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red; font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-size: large;\"><b>Chemoreceptors respond\nto <span style=\"color: blue;\">increases </span>in CO2,&nbsp; they are indifferent to decreases. In other words, they\nwon\u2019t cause you to stop breathing.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-size: large;\"><b>This is why people who hyperventilate can\ncontinue to do so for long periods of time; there\u2019s nothing to stop them, short\nof losing consciousness.</b></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hyperventilation, hyperactivates\nthe sympathetic nervous system, stressing the body more<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are many other\ninputs into the respiratory center as well, in particular from the cerebral\ncortex (the \u201cexecutive office\u201d of the brain, where conscious decisions are\nmade) and the limbic system (a group of areas of the brain concerned with\nemotion). It\u2019s not only physiology that determines breathing; emotions and conscious\ndecisions play a role too.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The voluntary, slow\ndeep breathing functionally resets the autonomic nervous system through\nstretch-induced inhibitory signals and hyperpolarization (slowing electrical\naction potentials) currents\u2026which synchronizes neural elements in the heart,\nlungs, limbic system and cortex.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Yoga participants learn\nhow to deal with distractions and stress without having an emotionally\nstimulating physiological response. They practice doing this by first\nrecognizing whatever the distraction or thought may be, and then returning or\nrestoring the focus of attention back to breathing.&nbsp;&nbsp; The re-focus centers on the thoughts \u201cI am\nbreathing\u201d <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Practices in yoga often\nfirst teach individuals to observe their own breathing to ultimately\nfamiliarize the student with the sensations of respiration. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Anatomically the\ndiaphragm sits beneath the lungs and is above the organs of the abdomen. It is\nthe separation between cavities of the torso (the upper or thoracic and the\nlower or abdominal). It is attached at the base of the ribs, the spine, and the\nsternum. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As, when the diaphragm\ncontracts the middle fibers, which are formed in a dome shape, descend into the\nabdomen, causing thoracic volume to increase (and pressure to fall), thus\ndrawing air into the lungs. The practice of proper breathing techniques is\naimed at eliminating misused accessory chest muscles, with more emphasis on\ndiaphragmatic breathing.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Diaphragmatic breathing\nshould be practiced in the supine, prone and erect positions, as these are the\nfunctional positions of daily life. Finally, the diaphragmatic breathing is\nintegrated with physical movements, asanas, during meditation and during\nrelaxation.. To get a full deep breath, learn how to breathe from the diaphragm\nwhile simultaneously expanding the chest.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Breathlessness is often\na response of your flight or fight hormone and nervous system triggering the\nneck and chest muscles to tighten. This makes breathing labored and gives a\nperson that breathless feeling.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Loss of carbon dioxide &nbsp;by hyperventilation triggers symptoms such as\ngasping, trembling, choking and the feeling of being smothered.&nbsp; Hyperventilation perpetuates more\noverbreathing, lowering carbon dioxide levels more, and thus become a nasty\nsequence. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Deep diaphragmatic breathing\nexercises (e.g. pranayama breathing) can enhance parasympathetic (inhibit\nneural responses) tone, decrease sympathetic (excitatory) nervous activity,\nimprove respiratory and cardiovascular function, decrease the effects of\nstress, and improve physical and mental health&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/zCLDHEtL4F8/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/zCLDHEtL4F8?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Carpopedal spasm occurs\nwhen acute hypocarbia causes reduced ionized calcium and phosphate levels,\nresulting in involuntary contraction of the feet or (more commonly) the hands <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Chvostek or Trousseau\nsigns may be positive because of hyperventilation-induced hypocalcemia<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Central nervous system\n(CNS) symptoms occur because hypocapnia causes cerebral artery vasoconstriction\nand reduced cerebral blood flow (CBF). CBF decreases by 2% for every 1 mm Hg\ndecrease in the arterial partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The symptoms of\ndizziness, weakness, confusion, and agitation are common. Patients may report\nfeelings of depersonalization and may experience visual hallucinations. Syncope\nor seizure may be provoked by hyperventilation. &nbsp;Paresthesias occur more commonly in the upper\nextremity and are usually bilateral. Perioral numbness is very common.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hyperventilation\nsyndrome (HVS) is defined as over-breathing in excess of the metabolic needs of\nthe body, removing more carbon dioxide than is produced and consequently\nresults in respiratory alkalosis and a wide range of somatic symptoms .&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Persistent respiratory alkalosis can induce secondary hypocalcemia and\nhypokalemia that may cause cardiac arrhythmias, conduction abnormalities, and\nvarious somatic symptoms such as paresthesia, hyperreflexia, convulsive\ndisorders, muscle spasm and tetany<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n<br /><span style=\"background-color: white; color: purple; font-size: large;\"><b>I ASK--&nbsp;</b></span></span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: purple; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: purple; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><b>CAN ILLITERATES LIKE BABA RAMDEV, SRI SRI RAVISHANKAR AND SADGURU JAGGI VAUDEV ( NO BASIC SCIENCE EDUCATION ) EVEN UNDERSTAND WHAT I HAVE WRITTEN ABOVE?</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"color: blue;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; font-size: large;\"><b>I AM A CHEMICAL SHIP CAPTAIN --&nbsp;&nbsp;</b></span></span></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; color: blue; font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; color: blue; font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; color: blue; font-size: large;\"><b>I AM TRAINED IN THIS--&nbsp; THESE ARE FUCKIN' BASICS&nbsp; !</b></span></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; color: purple; font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/6Og4lisjW30/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/6Og4lisjW30?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Carpopedal spasm occurs\nwhen acute hypocarbia causes reduced ionized calcium and phosphate levels,\nresulting in involuntary contraction of the feet or (more commonly) the hands <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Chvostek or Trousseau\nsigns may be positive because of hyperventilation-induced hypocalcemia<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Central nervous system\n(CNS) symptoms occur because hypocapnia causes cerebral artery vasoconstriction\nand reduced cerebral blood flow (CBF). CBF decreases by 2% for every 1 mm Hg\ndecrease in the arterial partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The symptoms of\ndizziness, weakness, confusion, and agitation are common. Patients may report\nfeelings of depersonalization and may experience visual hallucinations. Syncope\nor seizure may be provoked by hyperventilation. &nbsp;Paresthesias occur more commonly in the upper\nextremity and are usually bilateral. Perioral numbness is very common.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hyperventilation\nsyndrome (HVS) is defined as over-breathing in excess of the metabolic needs of\nthe body, removing more carbon dioxide than is produced and consequently\nresults in respiratory alkalosis and a wide range of somatic symptoms .&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Persistent respiratory alkalosis can induce secondary hypocalcemia and\nhypokalemia that may cause cardiac arrhythmias, conduction abnormalities, and\nvarious somatic symptoms such as paresthesia, hyperreflexia, convulsive\ndisorders, muscle spasm and tetany<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/09/marathon-running-secrets-of.html\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/09/marathon-running-secrets-of.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/09/marathon-running-secrets-of_16.html\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/09/marathon-running-secrets-of_16.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/09/marathon-running-secrets-of_17.html\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/09/marathon-running-secrets-of_17.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/09/marathon-running-secrets-of_20.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/09/marathon-running-secrets-of_20.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Tantra of SHIVA\nSWARODAYA is \"Phonetical astrology\"- the \"sound of one's own\nbreath\" --that deals with the significance of the changes in vital breath\nis called the svaraudaya<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Both SWARA YOGA and\nPRANAYAMA deal with Prana.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Pranayama\ninvolves techniques to redirect, tone and control prana-- and make the three\nand a half coiled snake of Kundalini wake up and HISSSSSSSS.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-eaqP7tnvf9E/Wm2UxCAvkgI/AAAAAAABYS4/5RZ8sE3AmH0sPtr8DZLCeGYtXlh4g3PwACLcBGAs/s1600/the-coils-of-kuDndalini_2.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"704\" data-original-width=\"614\" height=\"400\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-eaqP7tnvf9E/Wm2UxCAvkgI/AAAAAAABYS4/5RZ8sE3AmH0sPtr8DZLCeGYtXlh4g3PwACLcBGAs/s400/the-coils-of-kuDndalini_2.jpg\" width=\"348\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pranayama is for\nbeginners.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Swara yoga is about\nhighly technical and precise analysis of the breath and various pranic rhythms.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Shifting predominant\nbreath nostril by hyperventilation for a very short time is a part of Swara\nYoga.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A swara yogi is the\nultimate yogi.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; He knows how the sure\nway to charge the sperm of a polarity which can produce a male child.</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><i>Below:&nbsp; Sheetali Pranayama is a\ntranquilizing pranayama exercise designed to cool the body and reduce emotional\nexcitation by stimulating the parasympathetic nervous system. Sit in a\ncomfortable position and place your hands on your knees. Close your eyes. Stick\nyour tongue out and roll the outside edges of your tongue up toward each other\nto touch. Inhale through the hole made by your tongue. At the end of the\ninhalation, relax the tongue inside your mouth. Close your lips and exhale\nthrough your nostrils. With each breath increase the length of the inhale and\nexhale</i></span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/xQUdfm0l5ug/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/xQUdfm0l5ug?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><i>Below:&nbsp; Chandra (moon ) &nbsp;Bhedan ( piercing) -- breaking through &nbsp;is Chandra bhedi pranayama. &nbsp;Right nostril is surya nadi and left nostril\nis known as Chandra nadi. &nbsp;There is\nanother name for this Ida nadi (left nostril) and Pingala nadi (right nostril).\n&nbsp;Moon is the symbol of coolness, so by\ndoing this pranayama &nbsp;we feel some\ncoolness in our body. &nbsp;In his breathing\nexercise breathe in (inhalation) is done by the left nadi and we breathe out\nthrough the right nadi or right nostril. &nbsp;So this process is named as left nostril\nbreathing or Anuloma type of pranayam. Energy passes through Ida nadi (Chandra\nnadi) on the inhalation and by Pingala or Surya Nadi on the exhalation. These\nare larger nadis that hold the balance of magnetism and energy created by the\nsun and moon. They travel from the bottom of the spine to the purpose between\nthe eyebrows.</i></span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/c51tmW0LVE4/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/c51tmW0LVE4?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Below: The meaning of\n\u201cSurya\u201d is Sun and the meaning of the word \u201cBhedana\u201d is piercing.. The right\nnadi is the entrance way of Pingala Nadi, speaking to the sun vitality, the hot\nvitality or the manly vitality in our body.. In this process we use right nadi\n(right nostril) for breathe in (inhalation) and the left nostril for breath\nout. This process is also named as Viloma type of Pranayama. <o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>\n\n</i></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><i>Sit comfortably in\nPadmasana or Siddhasana. Keep your head and spine erect with eye closed. Shut\nyour left nostril with your ring finger and little finger. Now breathe in\n(inhale) slowly and deeply through your right nadi. After that, shut your right\nnadi with the thumb of your right hand.Then exhale through your left nostril,\nalong with keeping your right nostril closed. This is one cycle is completed. Repeat\nthis process around 5 \u2013 10 times.</i></span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><i><br /></i></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/E1hZeH_kfzM/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/E1hZeH_kfzM?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\">Below:&nbsp; In Shitali pranayama ( Sheetkari pranayama ) we\nbreathe through mouth.. These are same like a Python\u2019s breathing. &nbsp;&nbsp;It is very useful in cooling down the body\nand mind also. Performing 6 or 7 rounds of these processes can alleviate your\nthirst when you are feeling vey thirsty and there is no water available. In\nShitali we breathe through folding our tongue and in Sheetkari we inhale\nthrough teeth. Sit upright in a comfortable posture, keeping the head, neck,\nand spine erect. Close the eyes and relax the whole body. Place the hands in\nGyana Mudra. Open the lips and keep the teeth together. Hold the teeth\ntogether. Separate the lips, exposing the teeth. The tongue may be kept flat or\nfolded against the roof of the mouth (khechari mudra) Inhale through the teeth\nover the tongue with a kind of hissing sound like the sound of the letter \u2018s\u2019. After\nfilling the lungs completely, close the mouth and exhale through both nostrils\nwithout retention. Repeat five to ten times.</i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/Mf9DB7h-q5I/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/Mf9DB7h-q5I?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Below:&nbsp; Kaki pranayama is a\ncooling yogic breathing practice that is helpful when the body is overheated.. To\nbegin kaki pranayama, find a quiet place to sit in a seated position. Purse the\nlips, forming a small \u201cO\u201d shape (as if you were drinking out of a straw). On\nthe inhale, the breath is cooled before it fills the lungs. Exhale the breath\nout through the nose and repeat. Yogis can change the shape of the mouth for\ndifferent effects on the breath.&nbsp; Kaki\npranayama may referred to in English as beak breath as the pursed lips resemble\nthat of a crow's beak. Kaki pranayama can assist yogis in elongating their\ninhalation, which is helped by the pursed mouth shape. It can also assist in\nimproving respiratory health and slowing down the breath.&nbsp; Regular practice of kaki pranayama can lead\nto a long, disease-free life.. &nbsp;Kaki\npranayama is believed to open the anahata chakra, which is associated with\nrelationships, love and self-acceptance.</i></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/lVSiAAVi89o/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/lVSiAAVi89o?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: large;\">Below:&nbsp; The MMMMMM generates Nitric Oxide--the magic molecule</span></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-size: 12pt;\">The Bhramari pranayama\nbreathing technique derives its name from the black Indian bumblebee called\nBhramari. &nbsp;Bhramari pranayama is\neffective in instantly calming down the mind and it is INSTANT DESTRESS . Ensure\nthat you are not putting your finger inside the ear but on the cartilage.. It is\na simple to do breathing technique and can be practiced anywhere at work or\nhome.. In Bhramari Pranayama the exhalation sound is very resembles to the\nhumming sound of a bee. </span><span style=\"background-color: white; color: blue; font-size: large;\">Children score better arks in exams.&nbsp; &nbsp;Useless BONDHU employees\nget better in their work \u2013 gaining respect in office</span></i><span style=\"background-color: white; font-size: large;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/rd590U_4fII/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/rd590U_4fII?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Below:&nbsp; Kumbhaka ( pot ) is the\ncentral practice of traditional Hatha pranayama; there are two types of\nretention: after an inhale (antara), and after an exhale (bahya)..&nbsp; &nbsp;</i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><br /></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Keep the\nbody above the waist straight and the spine erect. Keep eyes closed. Make a\nshort exhalation and then start inhaling \u2013 slowly and rhythmically in one long\nand unbroken inspiration.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Continue inhaling until\na sense of fullness is experienced in the chest.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Retain the inhaled air\nfor a period of 10 seconds (preferably double the period of inspiration).<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Ensure: No exaggerated\nmovement of the abdomen.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>While sitting spine,\nhead and neck is maintained erect.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Ensure facial muscles\nrelaxed and nose is unconstricted.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Inhalation is slow and\nrhythmic \u2013 long, unbroken and without jerks.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Now exhale as naturally\nas possible \u2013 gradually, avoiding jerky or hasty movements.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Take few normal breaths\nand relax.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Practice daily, 5\nrounds/session, with pause in-between rounds.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Begin with a count of 5\nseconds inhalation and 10 seconds retention. Gradually increase it by 1\nsec/every week, when practised daily.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><br /></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Antar Kumbhaka/&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; It is ceasing of breath when the\ninhalation (or Poorak) is complete and the lungs are filled up with air. In\nthis kumbhaka, inhalation is recommended to be slightly forceful to take more\nair than normal and ceasing it as per one's ability.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Bahya Kumbhaka&nbsp;/&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; It is ceasing of breath when the\nexhalation (or Rechak) is complete. It is also recommended to exhale more than\nnormal and then cease it as per one's ability.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Sahit Kumbhaka&nbsp;/&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; It is the kumbhaka performed with\ninhalation or exhalation.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Kevali Kumbhaka&nbsp;/&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Inhalation or exhalation is not required\nor not focussed in exercising Kevali Kumbhaka.&nbsp; &nbsp;It is the extreme stage of\nKumbhaka which is attained only by continuous long term pranayama and kumbhak\nexercises.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Respiration includes\ninhalation and exhalation. In between these two processes there is a very\nminute gap or pause (normally in milliseconds) which is usually not noticed and\nit recurs, i.e., inhalation-pause-exhalation-pause-inhalation.... and it\ncontinues.&nbsp;</i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><br /></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>The maximum gap or pause is observed in the state of rest. Kumbhak\nenforces to increase the pause by ceasing the breath routinely and continuously\nby various types of pranayama and kumbhaka exercises.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>The more time spent for pranayama (and kumbhaka); the\nmore is the concentration and the better is the control over mind. Aging is\nalso seen proportional to frequency of respiration or respiratory rate, i.e.,\nfrequency of inhalation and exhalation in one minute. Medical science recorded\nnormal respiratory rate in humans as 12-16 breaths per minute with life span of\n70\u201380 years&nbsp;</i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><br /></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Practicing kumbhaka for a long time increases endurance of\nphysiological as well as psychological structure of an individual. Continuous\nand long term practicing increases the hold or control on breath up to an\nextent where it reaches to its extreme stage (Kevali Kumbhak) and the\nrespiration is ceased permanently unless desired to get into normal state.&nbsp;</i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><br /></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"background-color: white;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\">Aging\nis proportional to metabolism which in turn is proportional to respiratory\nrate. Metabolism lowers down as the respiratory rate decreases and this helps\nprevent aging or at least lowers down the process..</span></span><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><br /></i></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</i></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\">According to the Hatha\nYogic school, a Yogi who can suspend his breath by Kumbhaka for 20 minutes can\nhave a very good Dharana. He will have tranquillity of mind. Pranayama steadies\nthe mind, removes the Vikshepa and increases the power of concentration.</i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/Dam7osoYMMI/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/Dam7osoYMMI?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Among Nadis IDA is\nfemale while PINGALA is male<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-2cOxe3-BQf0/Wm2VESqETcI/AAAAAAABYS8/KAMjWuSD-ScKchvbh-I2TSob1aLrTLkQgCLcBGAs/s1600/84T54dba4b509b0ae59465ec806310fe4--kundalini-tattoo-kundalini-yoga.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em;
